slides.content:
# Introduction to Mechanics âš™ï¸

Welcome to **Mechanics** - the oldest and most fundamental branch of physics!

## What you'll learn:
- **Kinematics** - Describing motion mathematically
- **Forces & Newton's Laws** - Why objects move the way they do
- **Work, Energy & Power** - The currency of the physical world
- **Gravitation** - The force that shapes the universe
- **Momentum & Collisions** - Conservation laws in action

> ðŸ’¡ **Fun Fact:** Isaac Newton developed the laws of mechanics in 1687, and they're still used today to send rockets to space!

## Why Study Mechanics?
- ðŸš€ **Foundation of engineering** - Bridges, cars, rockets
- ðŸŒ **Explains everyday phenomena** - Why things fall, how engines work
- ðŸŽ¯ **Problem-solving skills** - Develops logical thinking
- ðŸ“ˆ **Gateway to advanced physics** - Essential for all other branches

Let's explore the science of motion!

slides.title: Kinematics: The Study of Motion
slides.content:
# Kinematics ðŸƒ

Kinematics describes **how** objects move without worrying about **why** they move.

## Key Quantities

| Quantity | Symbol | Unit | Description |
|----------|--------|------|-------------|
| **Position** | x, y | m | Location of object |
| **Displacement** | Î”x | m | Change in position |
| **Velocity** | v | m/s | Rate of position change |
| **Acceleration** | a | m/sÂ² | Rate of velocity change |

## Types of Motion

### 1. Uniform Motion
- Constant velocity
- Zero acceleration
- Example: Car on cruise control

### 2. Uniformly Accelerated Motion
- Constant acceleration
- Velocity changes linearly
- Example: Free-falling object

## Important Distinction

| Speed | Velocity |
|-------|----------|
| Scalar (magnitude only) | Vector (magnitude + direction) |
| Always positive | Can be negative |
| Distance/time | Displacement/time |

> ðŸŽ¯ **Key Point:** Velocity tells you how fast AND in which direction!

slides.title: Equations of Motion
slides.content:
# Equations of Motion ðŸ“

These equations relate position, velocity, acceleration, and time for **uniformly accelerated motion**.

## The Famous Four Equations

### Equation 1: Velocity-Time
```
v = u + at
```
- v = final velocity
- u = initial velocity
- a = acceleration
- t = time

### Equation 2: Displacement-Time
```
s = ut + Â½atÂ²
```

### Equation 3: Velocity-Displacement
```
vÂ² = uÂ² + 2as
```

### Equation 4: Average Velocity
```
s = Â½(u + v)t
```

## Example Problem

**A car accelerates from rest at 2 m/sÂ². Find its velocity after 5 seconds.**

| Given | Find |
|-------|------|
| u = 0 m/s | v = ? |
| a = 2 m/sÂ² | |
| t = 5 s | |

**Solution:** v = u + at = 0 + (2)(5) = **10 m/s**

> âš ï¸ **Remember:** These equations only work for constant acceleration!

slides.title: Newton's First Law: Inertia
slides.content:
# Newton's First Law: The Law of Inertia ðŸ”²

## The Law Statement

> *"An object at rest stays at rest, and an object in motion stays in motion with the same speed and direction, unless acted upon by an unbalanced force."*

## What is Inertia?

**Inertia** is the tendency of an object to resist changes in its state of motion.

### Key Points:
- âœ… Objects don't change motion on their own
- âœ… Mass is a measure of inertia
- âœ… More mass = more inertia = harder to accelerate

## Real-World Examples

| Situation | Inertia Effect |
|-----------|----------------|
| Sudden braking | Passengers lurch forward |
| Tablecloth trick | Dishes stay in place |
| Satellite in space | Continues forever (no friction) |
| Seatbelts | Prevent forward motion |

## Why Objects Stop on Earth

On Earth, objects slow down due to:
- ðŸŒ¬ï¸ Air resistance
- ðŸ›ž Friction
- ðŸŒŠ Drag forces

> ðŸ’¡ **Insight:** In the vacuum of space, a moving object would travel forever at constant velocity!

slides.title: Newton's Second Law: F = ma
slides.content:
# Newton's Second Law: Force and Acceleration âš¡

## The Law Statement

> *"The acceleration of an object is directly proportional to the net force acting on it and inversely proportional to its mass."*

## The Famous Equation

```
F = ma
```

| Symbol | Meaning | Unit |
|--------|---------|------|
| F | Net Force | Newton (N) |
| m | Mass | kilogram (kg) |
| a | Acceleration | m/sÂ² |

## Understanding the Relationship

### More Force â†’ More Acceleration
- Push harder, object accelerates faster
- Double the force, double the acceleration

### More Mass â†’ Less Acceleration
- Heavier objects are harder to accelerate
- Double the mass, half the acceleration

## Problem-Solving Strategy

1. **Identify** all forces acting on the object
2. **Draw** a free-body diagram
3. **Choose** a coordinate system
4. **Apply** F = ma in each direction
5. **Solve** for unknowns

## Example

**A 1000 kg car accelerates at 3 m/sÂ². What force is applied?**

F = ma = (1000 kg)(3 m/sÂ²) = **3000 N**

> ðŸŽ¯ **Remember:** 1 Newton is the force needed to accelerate 1 kg at 1 m/sÂ²

slides.title: Newton's Third Law: Action-Reaction
slides.content:
# Newton's Third Law: Action and Reaction ðŸ”„

## The Law Statement

> *"For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction."*

## Key Characteristics of Action-Reaction Pairs

| Property | Description |
|----------|-------------|
| **Equal magnitude** | Same strength |
| **Opposite direction** | 180Â° apart |
| **Different objects** | Act on different bodies |
| **Same type** | Both gravitational, both contact, etc. |

## Common Examples

### ðŸš€ Rocket Propulsion
- Action: Rocket pushes exhaust gases down
- Reaction: Gases push rocket up

### ðŸš¶ Walking
- Action: Foot pushes ground backward
- Reaction: Ground pushes foot forward

### ðŸŠ Swimming
- Action: Hands push water backward
- Reaction: Water pushes swimmer forward

## Common Misconception

âŒ **Wrong:** Action-reaction forces cancel out

âœ… **Correct:** They act on DIFFERENT objects, so they don't cancel!

## Free-Body Diagrams

When drawing free-body diagrams, only include forces acting **on** the object, not forces the object exerts on others.

> ðŸ’¡ **Key Insight:** Understanding which forces act on which object is crucial for problem-solving!

slides.title: Friction: The Resistive Force
slides.content:
# Friction ðŸ›ž

Friction is a force that **opposes relative motion** between surfaces in contact.

## Types of Friction

### 1. Static Friction (fs)
- Acts when objects are **not moving** relative to each other
- Can vary from 0 to a maximum value
- **fs â‰¤ Î¼s Ã— N** (where N is normal force)

### 2. Kinetic Friction (fk)
- Acts when objects are **sliding** against each other
- Has a constant value: **fk = Î¼k Ã— N**
- Always less than maximum static friction

## Coefficient of Friction (Î¼)

| Surface Pair | Î¼s | Î¼k |
|--------------|-------|-------|
| Rubber on dry concrete | 1.0 | 0.8 |
| Steel on steel | 0.74 | 0.57 |
| Ice on ice | 0.1 | 0.03 |
| Teflon on Teflon | 0.04 | 0.04 |

## Friction Graph

```

   | /

```

## Is Friction Good or Bad?

| Helpful Friction | Harmful Friction |
|------------------|------------------|
| Walking | Engine wear |
| Writing | Energy loss |
| Braking | Overheating |

> ðŸŽ¯ **Remember:** Friction depends on surface roughness and normal force, NOT on contact area!

slides.title: Work and Energy
slides.content:
# Work and Energy ðŸ’ª

## What is Work?

In physics, **work** is done when a force moves an object through a distance.

```
W = F Ã— d Ã— cos(Î¸)
```

| Symbol | Meaning | Unit |
|--------|---------|------|
| W | Work | Joule (J) |
| F | Force | Newton (N) |
| d | Distance | meter (m) |
| Î¸ | Angle between F and d | degrees |

## When is Work Done?

| Scenario | Work Done? | Why? |
|----------|------------|------|
| Pushing a box across floor | âœ… Yes | Force moves object |
| Holding a heavy book | âŒ No | No displacement |
| Carrying bag while walking | âŒ No | Force âŠ¥ to motion |
| Pushing wall | âŒ No | No displacement |

## Types of Energy

### Kinetic Energy (KE)
Energy of motion:
```
KE = Â½mvÂ²
```

### Potential Energy (PE)
Stored energy:
- **Gravitational:** PE = mgh
- **Elastic:** PE = Â½kxÂ²

## Work-Energy Theorem

> *"The net work done on an object equals its change in kinetic energy."*

```
W_net = Î”KE = Â½mvÂ²_final - Â½mvÂ²_initial
```

> ðŸ’¡ **Insight:** Work is the mechanism by which energy is transferred!

slides.title: Conservation of Energy
slides.content:
# Conservation of Energy âš¡

## The Principle

> *"Energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transformed from one form to another."*

## Total Mechanical Energy

```
E_total = KE + PE = constant (in absence of friction)
```

## Energy Transformations

### Falling Object
```
Top: All PE, No KE
  â†“
Middle: Half PE, Half KE
  â†“
Bottom: No PE, All KE
```

### Pendulum Swing
- Highest point: Maximum PE, Zero KE
- Lowest point: Zero PE, Maximum KE
- Energy continuously converts back and forth

## Problem-Solving with Energy

**Advantage:** No need to analyze forces during complex motion!

### Example: Roller Coaster

**A 500 kg cart starts from rest at height 20 m. Find its speed at the bottom.**

| At Top | At Bottom |
|--------|----------|
| PE = mgh = 500 Ã— 10 Ã— 20 | KE = Â½mvÂ² |
| = 100,000 J | = Â½ Ã— 500 Ã— vÂ² |

By conservation: 100,000 = 250vÂ²

v = **20 m/s**

## With Non-Conservative Forces

When friction is present:
```
E_initial = E_final + Energy_lost_to_friction
```

> ðŸŽ¯ **Power Tip:** Energy methods often simplify complex problems!

slides.title: Power: The Rate of Work
slides.content:
# Power âš¡

Power measures **how quickly** work is done or energy is transferred.

## Definition

```
P = W/t = Energy/time
```

| Symbol | Meaning | Unit |
|--------|---------|------|
| P | Power | Watt (W) |
| W | Work | Joule (J) |
| t | Time | second (s) |

## Alternative Formula

For constant force:
```
P = F Ã— v
```
- F = force applied
- v = velocity

## Power Units

| Unit | Equivalent |
|------|------------|
| 1 Watt | 1 J/s |
| 1 kilowatt (kW) | 1000 W |
| 1 Megawatt (MW) | 1,000,000 W |
| 1 Horsepower (hp) | 746 W |

## Common Power Ratings

| Device | Power |
|--------|-------|
| LED bulb | 10 W |
| Human (sustained) | 75 W |
| Microwave | 1000 W |
| Car engine | 100-200 kW |
| Power plant | 500-1000 MW |

## Efficiency

```
Efficiency = (Useful output power / Input power) Ã— 100%
```

No machine is 100% efficient due to friction and heat losses.

> ðŸ’¡ **Fun Fact:** A fit human can sustain about 75 W of power, but can briefly produce over 1000 W during sprinting!

slides.title: Gravitation
slides.content:
# Gravitation ðŸŒ

Gravity is the force of attraction between any two objects with mass.

## Newton's Law of Universal Gravitation

```
F = G Ã— (mâ‚ Ã— mâ‚‚) / rÂ²
```

| Symbol | Meaning | Value |
|--------|---------|-------|
| G | Gravitational constant | 6.67 Ã— 10â»Â¹Â¹ Nâ‹…mÂ²/kgÂ² |
| mâ‚, mâ‚‚ | Masses | kg |
| r | Distance between centers | m |

## Key Properties

1. **Always attractive** - Unlike electric forces
2. **Inverse square law** - Double distance = Â¼ force
3. **Acts through vacuum** - No medium needed
4. **Mutual** - Both objects experience equal forces

## Surface Gravity (g)

```
g = GM/RÂ²
```

| Planet | g (m/sÂ²) |
|--------|----------|
| Mercury | 3.7 |
| Earth | 9.8 |
| Mars | 3.7 |
| Jupiter | 24.8 |
| Moon | 1.6 |

## Weight vs. Mass

| Mass | Weight |
|------|--------|
| Amount of matter | Force of gravity |
| Scalar | Vector |
| Constant everywhere | Changes with location |
| Unit: kg | Unit: N (W = mg) |

> ðŸŽ¯ **Key Insight:** You weigh less on the Moon (W = mg), but your mass stays the same!

slides.title: Projectile Motion
slides.content:
# Projectile Motion ðŸŽ¯

Projectile motion is 2D motion under gravity only (ignoring air resistance).

## Key Principle

> *Horizontal and vertical motions are INDEPENDENT!*

| Horizontal | Vertical |
|------------|----------|
| ax = 0 | ay = -g |
| vx = constant | vy changes |
| x = vx Ã— t | y = vyâ‚€t - Â½gtÂ² |

## Trajectory Shape

Projectiles follow a **parabolic** path.

## Important Formulas

### Maximum Height
```
H = (vâ‚€sinÎ¸)Â² / (2g)
```

### Time of Flight
```
T = 2vâ‚€sinÎ¸ / g
```

### Range (horizontal distance)
```
R = vâ‚€Â²sin(2Î¸) / g
```

## Optimal Launch Angle

- **Maximum range:** 45Â°
- **Complementary angles** (like 30Â° and 60Â°) give same range

| Angle | Range | Max Height |
|-------|-------|------------|
| 30Â° | 0.87 R_max | Low |
| 45Â° | Maximum | Medium |
| 60Â° | 0.87 R_max | High |

## Real-World Applications

- ðŸ€ Basketball shots
- âš½ Football kicks
- ðŸ’§ Water fountains
- ðŸŽ† Fireworks

> ðŸ’¡ **Note:** In reality, air resistance modifies these ideal trajectories!

slides.title: Momentum
slides.content:
# Linear Momentum ðŸ’¨

## Definition

Momentum is the **quantity of motion** an object has.

```
p = m Ã— v
```

| Symbol | Meaning | Unit |
|--------|---------|------|
| p | Momentum | kgâ‹…m/s |
| m | Mass | kg |
| v | Velocity | m/s |

## Properties

- **Vector quantity** - Has direction
- **Depends on mass AND velocity**
- **Related to force:** F = Î”p/Î”t

## Impulse

**Impulse** is the change in momentum:

```
J = F Ã— Î”t = Î”p = m Ã— Î”v
```

## Impulse-Momentum Applications

| Application | How it works |
|-------------|-------------|
| Airbags | Increase Î”t â†’ Reduce F |
| Catching a ball | Move hand back â†’ Increase Î”t |
| Crumple zones | Extend collision time |
| Bungee jumping | Gradual deceleration |

## Comparing Momentum

| Object | Mass | Velocity | Momentum |
|--------|------|----------|----------|
| Bullet | 0.01 kg | 400 m/s | 4 kgâ‹…m/s |
| Tennis ball | 0.06 kg | 50 m/s | 3 kgâ‹…m/s |
| Car | 1000 kg | 10 m/s | 10,000 kgâ‹…m/s |

> ðŸŽ¯ **Key Point:** A slow, heavy object can have more momentum than a fast, light one!

slides.title: Conservation of Momentum
slides.content:
# Conservation of Momentum âš–ï¸

## The Principle

> *"In an isolated system (no external forces), total momentum remains constant."*

```
p_total(before) = p_total(after)
mâ‚vâ‚ + mâ‚‚vâ‚‚ = mâ‚vâ‚' + mâ‚‚vâ‚‚'
```

## Types of Collisions

### 1. Elastic Collision
- Kinetic energy IS conserved
- Objects bounce apart
- Example: Billiard balls

### 2. Inelastic Collision
- Kinetic energy NOT conserved
- Some energy â†’ heat, sound, deformation
- Example: Car crash

### 3. Perfectly Inelastic Collision
- Objects STICK together
- Maximum KE loss
- Example: Catching a ball

```
mâ‚vâ‚ + mâ‚‚vâ‚‚ = (mâ‚ + mâ‚‚)v_final
```

## Example Problem

**A 1 kg ball moving at 10 m/s collides with a stationary 2 kg ball. They stick together. Find the final velocity.**

| Before | After |
|--------|-------|
| pâ‚ = 1 Ã— 10 = 10 | p = 3 Ã— v |
| pâ‚‚ = 2 Ã— 0 = 0 | |
| Total = 10 kgâ‹…m/s | |

10 = 3v â†’ **v = 3.33 m/s**

> ðŸ’¡ **Application:** This principle explains how rockets work - expelling gas backward gives the rocket forward momentum!
